title: 104_hr2505
content: Automatic land bank protection is addressed in Section 1. The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act is amended to allow lands received in exchange from federal agencies to be conveyed to Native Corporations. Additionally, lands exchanged among Native Corporations will not be considered developed, leased, or sold to a third party as a result of the exchange. The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act is amended to allow the exchange of land or interest in land between Native Corporations and trusts, partnerships, corporations, or joint ventures whose beneficiaries are Native Corporations. Trustee actions serving Native Corporations are also included in the amendment. SEC. 2. RETAINED MINERAL ESTATE. Section 12(c)(4) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to allow Regional Corporations to request conveyance of public lands surrounded by their subsurface lands. The total acreage limit for such conveyances is set at 12,000 acres, and selections cannot be made from lands within a conservation system unit. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows Regional Corporations to request conveyance of public lands within their subsurface lands, with an acreage limit of 12,000 acres. The election to obtain public lands must include all available parcels within the township, and the term 'Regional Corporation' refers specifically to Doyon, Limited. SEC. 3 proposes an amendment to Public Law 102-415 regarding the conveyance of land to Gold Creek under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. CIRI is granted rights to in-lieu subsurface estate within 1 year. SEC. 4 involves a land exchange with Calista Corporation. Congress finds that the land exchange authorized by Public Law 102-172 should be implemented without delay. The lands involved are within the boundaries of the Yukon Delta National Wildlife Refuge and are crucial habitat for waterfowl and other birds in the Pacific flyway. The Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta Region is important habitat for various wildlife species such as geese, ducks, bears, moose, and fish. The acquisition of lands in this region would further the purposes of the refuge established by ANILCA. The region also faces serious economic, social, and health challenges. The Calista Corporation, a Native Regional Corporation in Alaska, has responsibilities under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to address social, cultural, economic, health, and subsistence issues in the Yukon Delta National Wildlife Refuge region, which faces serious challenges including high rates of infant mortality, teenage suicide, hepatitis, alcoholism, and unemployment. The Calista Corporation, a Native Regional Corporation in Alaska, has responsibilities under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to address social, cultural, economic, health, and subsistence issues in the Yukon Delta National Wildlife Refuge region. The implementation of a land exchange is essential for Calista to utilize its assets and realize the benefits of ANCSA. Congress is urged to authorize and direct the implementation of this exchange to further the goals of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act and the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. The Calista Corporation, a Native Regional Corporation in Alaska, requires a land exchange to fulfill its obligations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The amendment specifies changes to the implementation timeline and valuation process for the exchange. The amendment specifies changes to the implementation timeline and valuation process for the land exchange required by the Calista Corporation, a Native Regional Corporation in Alaska, under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. This includes establishing aggregate values of lands and interests as of January 1, 1997, adjusting property account amounts, and extending the restriction on certain property transfers until October 1, 2002. The amendment to Section 8126(c) of Public Law 102-172 involves changes to the land exchange timeline and valuation process for Calista Corporation under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. It establishes a property account on January 1, 1997, adjusts account amounts based on agreed values, and allows for use as specified. The amendment establishes a property account on January 1, 1997, with funds available for use in two parts on specific dates. Any remaining value on October 1, 2002, will be credited to the account. The amendment allows Calista Corporation or village corporations to assign account funds upon notification to the Treasury and Interior Secretaries. Calista must provide documentation and maps for land exchanges to the Bureau of Land Management. The amendment allows Calista Corporation to provide information to the Secretary of the Treasury as required, including minor boundary adjustments with the Department. Revenues generated will be calculated according to the CCRD Addendum for the applicability of section 7(i) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. SEC. 5 amends section 22(c) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to include Haida Corporation and Haida Traditional Use Sites as Regional Corporations, with revenues not subject to distribution under section 7(i). SEC. 6 addresses the sale or use of various resources like sand, gravel, and stone. Section 7 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to exempt certain resources like sand, gravel, and stone from revenue distribution to Regional Corporations. This change does not affect ownership of these resources. SEC. 7 of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act is amended to apply certain conditions to Alaska Native allotment applications. SEC. 8 addresses visitor services. SEC. 8 of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act is amended to address visitor services by updating language regarding Native Corporations. Within nine months of enactment, the Secretary of the Interior must submit a report to Congress detailing local hire actions and recruitment processes under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. The report should also cover local contracts with Alaska. The Secretary of Agriculture will assist in this process for the Forest Service. The Secretary of the Interior contracts with Alaska Native Corporations for services on public lands in Alaska. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 26, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
